Would be cool if a client could keep spamming the bls pool with unverified signatures, and with bls changes that would overwrite the original address.

author: potuz
content: if you're planning to DOS then I suggest you start spamming after the fork and without anything on clients' pools. The paths to rejection before the fork on libp2p are well tested already

author: potuz
content:
<@412614104222531604> I'm pushing an image that will do the following: 
- It will accept any bls change that you give to the endpoint, valid or not. 
- it will not broadcast those messages
- It will pack them in blocks that the validators propose. 

So use this to send bad blocks on a devnet. You will need to generate bad data (or good) as you want (I believe <@861686400893583370> is working on a fuzzer) and submit them to the endpoint as you normally do. This endpoint will send the bad blocks.

author: barnabasbusa
content: why would it not broadcast the messages ?

author: potuz
content: <@498009160982724610>  is going to do that one, the thing is that if we broadcast the messages the node will be banned and then it will be disconnected by the time it needs to propose

author: barnabasbusa
content: ah makes sense

author: potuz
content: So we need different nodes to broadcast bad blocks from the nodes that broadcast bad messages

author: barnabasbusa
content: I'm thinking we should do some valid some invalid ones

content: sure

content: In order to run the new image, ansible has to be run. To do that, you can clone the withdrawals repo, and run ```ansible-playbook -i withdrawal-mainnet-shadowfork-1/inventory/inventory.ini playbooks/update_execution_beacon_and_validator.yml -l 'prysm'```

content: and if you change the prysm image in the inventory/group_vars/prysm.yaml then it will use the new image
